thread.title: Ducks special teams rebounding after allowing 'best play I've ever seen' against Utah: Oregon Ducks rundown
thread.title_full: Ducks special teams rebounding after allowing 'best play I've ever seen' against Utah: Oregon Ducks rundown | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Greif | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Ducks special teams rebounding after allowing 'best play I've ever seen' against Utah: Oregon Ducks rundown
text:
EUGENE — Tom Osborne, Oregon's coach for special teams and tight ends, is a firm believer that not enough credit is given in college football.
So when the Ducks' punt coverage unit was caught flat-footed by "the best play I've seen in all my years of coaching in college football," last Saturday against Utah, Osborne made sure to cross Rich Brooks Field at Autzen Stadium after Utah's 62-20 rout and give the Utes their due.
"I went over and shook their hands afterward," said Osborne, whose coaching career began in 1986 at Portland State. "There's nothing our guys did anything wrong. They ran a trick play, they rolled the dice and they hit the jackpot. Never seen it in college football."
The play began as an innocuous as they come; one of seven punts the Ducks (2-2, 0-1 Pac-12) would kick in their worst home loss since 1977. From his own 35-yard line, punter Ian Wheeler booted his kick down the left sideline to the Utah 31, where Boobie Hobbs stood waiting in front of the Oregon bench after peeling off from his assignment jamming a UO "gunner."
Problem was, the rest of Oregon's coverage team followed instructions and ran toward the right sideline, where returner Britain Covey had baited everyone but Wheeler, who could follow the flight of his ball, and one other coverage man.
Covey even faked out Fox's camera operator.
Hobbs' eventual touchdown went for 69 yards to give Utah a 55-13 lead, the first punt returned for a score against the Ducks since Nov. 15, 2007.
"I could see (Hobbs) bail before the snap of the ball but what was he bailing for?" Osborne said. "I thought he was bailing for a throwback to him but how are those guys on the field supposed to know that? They can't hear anything if you're yelling out there, it's too loud. It's a trick play that was executed perfectly and the ball was kicked right to the guy, what can you say.
"They can't hear you on the field. We're screaming things all the time on the field and they can't hear it."
Hobbs' touchdown was not the only special teams gaffe of the night — Utah punter Tom Hackett, later named the Pac-12's special teamer of the week, rushed for 33 yards on fourth-and-13, and Bralon Addison lost a punt in the sun, which led to a 76-yard Hackett punt — which brings the typically spotless unit into the spotlight Saturday when UO travels to Colorado (3-1, 0-0).
Hackett said P12 POTW just means no returner did something special. On Hobbs: "Boobie was all by him-bloody-self. I could have done that."
— Matthew Piper (@matthew_piper) September 28, 2015
Byron Marshall, who is "week-to-week" after injuring a leg during a kick return against Utah, will not play, which hurts UO's production as his 27.5 yards per return were 18th-most nationally. Charles Nelson is listed on the depth chart as his kickoff replacement, alongside usual returner Bralon Addison.
Running back Tony Brooks-James, corner Ugo Amadi, all-purpose back Kirk Merritt and receiver Devon Allen also are in the rotation to receive kicks if needed, Osborne said.
Among FBS teams, Colorado's highest-ranked special teams unit is kick return, where its 27.8-yard average ranks 14th-best nationally. The Ducks, by comparison, have not allowed a touchdown on a kick return since 2006.
The Buffaloes have averaged just 4.4 yards on punts, but rankings can be a misnomer — Utah's punt return unit ranked just 61st, too, before its fake-out of the Ducks.
This weekend, Osborne would prefer to heap the credit on his team.
"Our punt coverage is great," Osborne said. 'That's a frickin' awesome play right there. That was an awesome play. Give them credit."

— Andrew Greif
agreif@oregonian.com
